section.title: Overview
section.para: The CeltiXfire documentation uses a subset of the linking elements defined by DocBook. The elements include:
Using this set of elements, you can create cross references, internal links, and external links in your documents.

section.title: Internal Links and Cross References
section.para: Internal links are links whose anchor is in the same document. A cross reference is a special instance of an internal link. Where an internal link requires that you supply the text that is displayed, as with an HTML link, a cross reference's text is automatically determined by the link's target.

section.title: Inserting an Internal Link
section.para: Internal links are created using the link element. The link element has one required attribute linkend whose value is the id of element anchoring the link. The anchoring element can be any valid DocBook element that uses the id attribute. For example if you wanted to create a link to an image in your document, you could use the id of the figure element that wraps the image.

note.para: You can also create anchor points in your text using the anchor element. In this case, the value of the linkend attribute would be the id of the anchor element.

section.para: The text used for the link is the content of the link element. shows the mark up for this link to the top of this section.

example.title: Example of an Internal Link
example.programlisting: this <link linkend="link">link to the top</link> of

section.title: Inserting a Cross Reference
section.para: Cross references are created using the xref element. Like the link element, the xref element requires the use of the linkend attribute to identify the element being referenced.

Unlike the link element, the xref element does not have any contents. The text displayed for the generated link is generated based on the contents of the referenced element. If the referenced element has a title element, such as a section element or a example element, the contents of the title element is used as the link text. Alternatively, the value of the referenced element's xreflabel attribute will be used as the link text.

note.para: If the referenced element has both a title element and a value specified in its xreflabel attribute, the value of the xreflabel attribute is used.

section.para: shows an example of a cross reference whose text is derived from the title element of the referenced element. The resulting link text would be the section called "Coco Crisp" shows.

section.para: shows an example of a cross reference whose text is derived from the xreflabel attribute of the referenced element. The resulting link text would be short stop shows .

example.programlisting: <para><xref linkend="example1" /> shows ...</para> ... <example id="example1" xreflabel="short stop"> <title>Catching Coco Crisp</title> ... </example>

section.title: External Links
section.para: External links are links to resources that are not contained in the same XML source document. They do not have to be links to other documents. They can be links to Web pages or any other resource that can be reached using a URL. Generally, they are transformed into HTML links when the document is published.
External links are created using the ulink element. You identify the linked resource using the required url attribute. The value must be a valid URL.

note.para: Because the CeltiXfire documentation is built with Forrest, you can use the site:siteId resource identifier to refer to pages that are listed in site.xml.

section.para: The link text can be specified in one of two ways. You can specified the desired link text as the value of the ulink element. If you leave the ulink element empty, the value of the url attribute will be used as the link text.
